verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, 'Cut for yourself two stone tablets like the first ones, and I will write on the tablets the words that were on the first tablets, which you broke.'
verses.comment: God calls Moses to remake the tablets, showing both divine justice and mercy. The initiative belongs to God, who restores what was lost through human failure.

verses.text: 'Be ready by morning, and come up in the morning to Mount Sinai, and present yourself there to Me on the top of the mountain.'
verses.comment: Moses is told to prepare and ascend alone, indicating a sacred meeting. The early morning marks a time of new beginnings, paralleling resurrection motifs.

verses.text: 'No one shall come up with you, and let no one be seen anywhere on the mountain; neither let the flocks nor herds graze in front of that mountain.'
verses.comment: God's holiness demands separation; only Moses may approach. The restrictions emphasize the gravity of divine encounter, foreshadowing the unique role of spiritual mediation.

verses.text: So Moses cut two stone tablets like the first. He rose early in the morning and went up Mount Sinai, as the LORD had commanded him, and took the two stone tablets in his hand.
verses.comment: Moses’ obedience and preparation are highlighted. His actions prefigure dedicated service and sacramental preparation for meeting God.

verses.text: The LORD descended in the cloud and stood there with him, and proclaimed the name of the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s descent in the cloud recalls His presence in the tabernacle, showing both transcendence and immanence. The proclamation of His name is a declaration of His character.

verses.text: The LORD passed before him and proclaimed, 'The LORD, the LORD, a God merciful and gracious, slow to anger, and abounding in steadfast love and faithfulness,'
verses.comment: God reveals His innermost nature: mercy, grace, patience, and faithfulness. This description will echo throughout Scripture and is foundational for understanding divine love and covenant.

verses.text: 'keeping steadfast love for thousands, forgiving iniquity and transgression and sin, but who will by no means clear the guilty, visiting the iniquity of fathers upon the children and the children's children, to the third and fourth generation.'
verses.comment: God both forgives and judges, balancing mercy and justice. The generational consequences imply the deep reach of sin, but also the far greater reach of mercy for those who love Him.

verses.text: Moses quickly bowed his head toward the earth and worshipped.
verses.comment: Encountering God’s glory leads to worship and humility. True worship is a response to divine revelation.

verses.text: He said, 'If now I have found favor in Your sight, O Lord, let the Lord go among us, for it is a stiff-necked people; pardon our iniquity and our sin, and take us as Your inheritance.'
verses.comment: Moses serves as mediator, asking for forgiveness and ongoing presence. The idea of God’s people as His 'inheritance' reveals their special status. Mediation points ahead to Christ’s intercessory priesthood.

verses.text: He said, 'Behold, I am making a covenant. Before all your people, I will do wonders never before done in all the earth or in any nation, so that all the people among whom you live may see the work of the LORD. For it is a fearful thing that I am about to do with you.'
verses.comment: God’s renewal of covenant comes with a promise of unique signs, marking Israel as God’s elect. The language of marvels prepares for later saving acts, fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: 'Observe what I command you this day. Behold, I will drive out before you the Amorite, the Canaanite, the Hittite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite.'
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s command is key to enjoying the blessings of His covenant. The conquest is part of God’s plan to establish His people in holiness.

verses.text: 'Take care, lest you make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land where you go, lest it become a snare among you.'
verses.comment: The warning against foreign covenants preserves purity of worship. Spiritual fidelity is essential for union with God.

verses.text: 'You shall tear down their altars, break their pillars, and cut down their Asherah poles.'
verses.comment: True worship requires the removal of competing loyalties. Purging idolatry guards against spiritual compromise.

verses.text: 'For you shall not worship any other god, for the LORD, whose name is Jealous, is a jealous God.'
verses.comment: God’s jealousy is the passionate love of a covenant partner, desiring singular devotion, prefiguring the relationship Christ has with His Church.

verses.text: 'Lest you make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land, and when they prostitute themselves to their gods and sacrifice to them, someone invites you, and you eat of his sacrifice,'
verses.comment: Participation in idol feasts leads to spiritual compromise. Fidelity is tested by everyday choices regarding worship.

verses.text: 'and you take some of their daughters for your sons, and their daughters prostitute themselves to their gods and make your sons prostitute themselves to their gods,'
verses.comment: Intermarriage with idol-worshipers is repeatedly condemned for its effect on faithfulness; spiritual unity is deeper than societal bonds.

verses.text: 'You shall not make for yourself any gods of cast metal.'
verses.comment: God reiterates the absolute ban on images, maintaining the holiness and transcendence of His reality versus idols.

verses.text: 'You shall keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread. Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, as I commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Abib; for in the month of Abib you came out from Egypt.'
verses.comment: The institution of the feast roots worship in historical deliverance and ritual remembrance, which are central to spiritual formation. The importance of communal sacred memory is emphasized.

verses.text: 'All that opens the womb is Mine; all your male livestock, the firstborn of cow and sheep.'
verses.comment: Dedication of the firstborn affirms God’s sovereign possession of all life and recalls the deliverance in Egypt. This hints at patterns fulfilled later in the dedication of Christ (Luke 2:23).

verses.text: 'The firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb, or if you do not redeem it, you shall break its neck. All the firstborn of your sons you shall redeem. No one shall appear before Me empty-handed.'
verses.comment: Redemption of the firstborn, especially by a lamb, points forward to sacrificial substitution—fulfilled ultimately in the Lamb of God (John 1:29).

verses.text: 'Six days you shall work, but on the seventh day you shall rest; in plowing time and in harvest you shall rest.'
verses.comment: Sabbath rest is commanded even during the busiest times, teaching about dependence on God. This rhythm of work and rest becomes a sign of covenant relationship.

verses.text: 'You shall observe the Feast of Weeks, the firstfruits of wheat harvest, and the Feast of Ingathering at the year's end.'
verses.comment: Annual feasts anchor worship in agricultural cycles, linking everyday life with divine providence and sacred time.

verses.text: 'Three times in the year all your males shall appear before the Lord GOD, the God of Israel.'
verses.comment: Pilgrimage to worship binds community together and affirms unique relationship with God. These gatherings foreshadow the fullness of communal worship in God’s spiritual household.

verses.text: 'For I will cast out nations before you and enlarge your borders; no one shall covet your land when you go up to appear before the LORD your God three times in the year.'
verses.comment: God promises supernatural protection during obedience, encouraging trust. The link between worship and blessing is again reinforced.

verses.text: 'You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with anything leavened, nor shall the sacrifice of the Feast of Passover remain until the morning.'
verses.comment: Unleavened offerings highlight purity. The prohibition against leftover sacrifice establishes the importance of complete devotion and hints at the sacred character of sacrificial worship.

verses.text: 'The best of the firstfruits of your ground you shall bring to the house of the LORD your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.'
verses.comment: Sacrificial offering of firstfruits is tied to gratitude and recognition of God’s provision. The food law suggests rejection of pagan ritual practices.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses, 'Write these words, for in accordance with these words I have made a covenant with you and with Israel.'
verses.comment: Writing the covenant words preserves them for all generations, revealing the importance of Scripture for sustaining faith and unity.

verses.text: So Moses was there with the LORD forty days and forty nights; he neither ate bread nor drank water. He wrote on the tablets the words of the covenant, the Ten Commandments.
verses.comment: Forty days and nights emphasize Moses’ total devotion and God’s sustaining presence. The parallel with Christ’s forty-day fast points to fulfillment of the law in Him; the written law as foundation for God’s people.

verses.text: When Moses came down from Mount Sinai with the two tablets of the testimony in his hand, as he came down from the mountain, Moses did not know that the skin of his face shone because he had been talking with God.
verses.comment: Moses’ radiant face marks the transformative effect of being in God’s presence. The radiance foreshadows the spiritual transformation promised to all who encounter God through new covenant worship.

verses.text: Aaron and all the people of Israel saw Moses, and behold, the skin of his face shone. They were afraid to come near him.
verses.comment: God’s holiness inspires awe and fear in the people, indicating reverence that ultimately leads back to worship and union with God.

verses.text: But Moses called to them, and Aaron and all the leaders of the congregation returned to him, and Moses spoke with them.
verses.comment: The role of Moses as mediator reconciles the people’s fear with God’s desire for relationship, paralleling the priestly ministry that brings God’s people near.

verses.text: Afterward, all the people of Israel came near, and he commanded them all that the LORD had spoken to him on Mount Sinai.
verses.comment: Moses communicates God's will to the assembly, highlighting the principle of authoritative revelation and transmission of divine law.

verses.text: When Moses had finished speaking with them, he put a veil over his face.
verses.comment: The veil over Moses’ face points to the mystery and partiality of old covenant revelation, which is later unveiled in the fullness of Christ.

verses.text: Whenever Moses went before the LORD to speak with Him, he would remove the veil until he came out. Then he would come out and tell the people of Israel what he was commanded.
verses.comment: Moses’ unveiled approach to God models intimacy in prayer and exemplifies the eventual openness believers receive through divine grace.

verses.text: The people of Israel would see Moses’ face shining, and Moses put the veil on his face again until he went in to speak with Him.
verses.comment: The recurring veil underscores both reverence and mystery surrounding God’s presence, suggesting layers of revelation completed through Christ, the ultimate Mediator. Union with God is made possible by transformation through the Spirit.
